channel.title: NYT > Home Page
channel.description: New York Times > Breaking News, World News & Multimedia

item.title: Shadow of Vietnam Falls Over Iraq River Raids
item.author: By JOHN F. BURNS
item.description: As marines aboard patrol boats roared up the Euphrates on a dawn raid on Sunday, images pressed in of another American war.

item.title: Iran Backs Away From a Demand on A-Bomb Fuel
item.author: By ELAINE SCIOLINO
item.description: The Iranian retreat appeared to salvage a nuclear deal reached Nov. 15 between Iran and France, Britain and Germany.

item.title: Trying to Avoid 2nd Caesarean, Many Find Choice Isn't Theirs
item.author: By DENISE GRADY
item.description: More and more hospitals that once allowed vaginal birth after Caesarean are now insisting on repeat Caesareans.

item.title: Premier's Camp Signals a Threat to Ukraine Unity
item.author: By C. J. CHIVERS
item.description: As many as 3,500 officials voted to seek autonomy if the opposition continues to seek the presidency for Viktor A. Yushchenko.

item.title: L.I. Clash on Immigrants Is Gaining Political Force
item.author: By PATRICK HEALY
item.description: The issue of illegal immigration is gathering political force in Long Island, and as the complaints grow, politicians are responding with new laws.

item.title: The Bonus: A Rise in the Number Wall St. Crunches the Most
item.author: By JENNY ANDERSONand LANDON THOMAS Jr.
item.description: Year-end bonuses for investment bankers are expected to rise 10 percent to 15 percent from last year, executives and compensation experts say.

item.title: Ridge, First Secretary of U.S. Security, Is Quitting His Post
item.author: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON and DAVID JOHNSTON
item.description: The country's first secretary of homeland security plans to leave by Feb. 1, unless a successor is confirmed before then.

item.title: U.N. Report Urges Big Changes; Security Council Would Expand
item.author: By WARREN HOGE
item.description: The U.N. proposed the most sweeping changes in its history and recommended the overhaul of its key decision-making arm.

item.title: Court Panel Says New York Schools Need Billions More
item.author: By GREG WINTER
item.description: A panel has found that an additional $5.6 billion must be spent on schoolchildren every year to provide a basic education.

item.title: In Falluja's Ruins, Big Plans and a Risk of Chaos
item.author: By ROBERT F. WORTH
item.description: As officials prepare to start letting residents return to Falluja, Iraq, they must figure out how to win back the confidence of the people whose city they have destroyed.

item.title: U.S. Rules Out Dam Removal to Aid Salmon
item.author: By FELICITY BARRINGER
item.description: The Bush administration will not remove federal dams on the Columbia and Snake Rivers to protect 11 endangered species of salmon and steelhead, even as a last resort.

item.title: Pension Fund of New York Files Suit Against Merck
item.author: By BARRY MEIER
item.description: The main pension fund of New York State filed a lawsuit against Merck & Company, accusing it of misleading shareholders about the safety of its pain drug Vioxx.
